description.en:
The course will help to build a foundation of image processing knowledge on top of preexisting skill of programming, some of which is preferably in Python. The content will be mainly targeted at Master's level students. 
Seminars consist of presenting research results or chapters from the textbook, and discussion. Lab sessions comprise (of) understanding how the core principles of image processing work and how to implement them. 
The content may include, but is not limited to the following: image formation, compression and representation, colour spaces, pattern recognition, depth and stereo imaging, segmentation, some ML.
description.et:
The course will help to build a foundation of image processing knowledge on top of preexisting skill of programming, some of which is preferably in Python. The content will be mainly targeted at Master's level students. 
Seminars consist of presenting research results or chapters from the textbook, and discussion. Lab sessions comprise (of) understanding how the core principles of image processing work and how to implement them. 
The content may include, but is not limited to the following: image formation, compression and representation, colour spaces, pattern recognition, depth and stereo imaging, segmentation, some ML.

objectives.en: The main objective of this course is to give a systematic understanding of image processing techniques to Master's level (or advanced Bachelor's level) students using practical assignments, seminars and a project.
objectives.et: The main objective of this course is to give a systematic understanding of image processing techniques to Master's level (or advanced Bachelor's level) students using practical assignments, seminars and a project.

learning_outcomes.en: Having passed the course, the successful student is expected to be improved in understanding:
learning_outcomes.et: Having passed the course, the successful student is expected to be improved in understanding:

learning_outcomes.en: * convolution, inertia, convexity, eigenvectors and eigenvalues;
learning_outcomes.et: * convolution, inertia, convexity, eigenvectors and eigenvalues;

learning_outcomes.en: * the colour spaces used for images;
learning_outcomes.et: * the colour spaces used for images;

learning_outcomes.en: * methods compensating for non-ideal light conditions;
learning_outcomes.et: * methods compensating for non-ideal light conditions;

learning_outcomes.en: * determining the hardware limitations of the capturing system;
learning_outcomes.et: * determining the hardware limitations of the capturing system;

learning_outcomes.en: * build an end-to-end image processing pipeline;
learning_outcomes.et: * build an end-to-end image processing pipeline;

notes.et:
The material is fairly new - do expect some changes and deviations during the semester.

We will have one 2h timeslot and one 4h timeslot each week for on-site activities with an optional 2h consultation every other week. All of this takes place Wednesdays and Thursdays.

The use of ChatGPT or any other AI-based software is not allowed in the course.

grade_evaluation.et:
Laboratory practicals - 32%
* Completion of all practical tasks is mandatory
Seminar presentations - 16%
* Attendance mandatory: 75% of seminars
Lectures
* Attendance is strongly advised
Midterm - 24%
* Oral examination - covers topics of the first ~half of the semester 
Project - 28%
* Will start after the midterm
* Will have one intermediate deadline and a final demo

Assuming that all compulsory activities have been completed, the score will be converted to a final grade as follows:
* >=91% -> A
* >=81% -> B
* >=71% -> C
* >=61% -> D
* >=51% -> E
* Else -> F

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

description.et: We aim to have around 4 lectures during the semester. Starting with intro to the course mixed with some theory and followed by 3 lectures focusing on some core topics distributed over the semester.
A midterm on the topics of the first ~half of the semester covering the classical components of image processing.
Seminars will happen in the same weekly timeslot with the lectures. We aim to have 12 seminars alternating with the lectures. Exact distribution is fixed at a later time.

audience.et: Learners with a background in computer science, robotics, electrical and electronics engineering, informatics, computer engineering, automation, or a related field
